stem: The nurse in a psychiatric unit is reviewing the clinical trends for three clients on antipsychotic therapy. Based on the documentation, match each assessment finding to the appropriate adverse reaction.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: 34-year-old male on haloperidol. He is unable to sit still and is constantly pacing the unit. Reports feeling 'restless in my skin'.
Patient B: 29-year-old female on fluphenazine. Her neck is twisted to the side, and her tongue is protruding. She appears highly distressed.
Patient C: 50-year-old male on risperidone. He presents with a high fever (103.2°F), severe 'lead-pipe' muscle rigidity, and tachycardia.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: Patient C: BP 160/100, Temp 39.5°C, HR 128. Diaphoretic.

rows.text: Restlessness, pacing, and inability to sit still
Sudden, spastic contraction of the neck (torticollis)
Muscle rigidity, hyperpyrexia, and autonomic instability

rationale.correct: Akathisia (r1) presents as restlessness and pacing. Acute dystonia (r2) is characterized by painful muscle contractions such as torticollis. NMS (r3) is a life-threatening emergency defined by lead-pipe rigidity and high fever. Tardive dyskinesia (r4) involves long-term, irreversible involuntary movements of the face and tongue.
clinicalPearls: The NMS triad includes fever, rigidity, and autonomic instability.
Benztropine (Cogentin) is a primary treatment for acute dystonia.
Akathisia is often mistaken for worsening psychosis; avoid increasing the antipsychotic dosage.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: NMS is characterized by rigidity (lead-pipe), while serotonin syndrome presents with hyperreflexia (clonus/twitching).

mnemonic.title: The EPS Order
mnemonic.expansion: ADAL: Acute Dystonia (Hours), Akathisia (Days), Late TD (Months/Years).
